It’s not an overstatement to say that BNHA’s popularity has sky-rocketed since it made its debut 2 years ago and that it’s now with all certainty the big shounen sensation from the 2010s following the footsteps of Naruto in the 00s and Dragon Ball in the 90s. With its 3rd season now over, is BNHA (a.k.a. Naruto meets MCU meets Harry Potter), living up to its plus-ultra hype? Briefly, this season at least, not so much. It is with no question a step back from the great previous season, but not to the point that we should raise the alarms and lose hope on it.



Plot and story development:



First season introduced us the world and characters. Deku inherits a quirk from his idol All Might and is accepted at UA, the most prestigious hero school in Japan. The second -along with Deku- developed some side-characters within a fascinating tournament arc; the same within a dark, serious villain arc; it showed us Deku training to control his quirk in Master Yoda-trains-Luke fashion; it gave us more school classes and exams here and there to understand the meaning of being a hero, and set the stage for a future clash among our heroes and gathering villains. Now the third one is still more or less doing the same as the second, but things are starting to get somewhat messy. 


Contrary to S2, the important arc came first and the not-so-important arc came after. Not a very smart move to build tension I’d say. And the quality contrast this time was sharp. The first one was so great that it made the second pale in comparison. If BNHA was a straight long-runner this wouldn’t have felt much a problem, because the “meh” arc would have been “sandwiched” by another more substantial one working as the other side of the bread. 


The show starts weak with a recap + unnecessary fanservice-ish episode to remember the audience what has been shown so far and where are we standing that could just have been a separate special rather than part of the series. I don’t really think the intention was to showcase the swimming skills of our male cast honestly, but who cares, it’s just one episode and that’s it. You don’t crucify FMAB for having a recap episode right in the middle of the show. If you didn’t mind that, I see no reason why you should mind now. Also no episode aside the special ones is useless. No episode feels disposable. Even the dorms episode provided a lot of fun showing our cast making a best-decorated room contest and having fun doing that.


The first arc, the forest camp training arc, showcases our students training to enhance their quirks and the League of Villains interrupting these school activities once again, this time to scare the class, make them feel unsafe in this dangerous world they truly live in, and to kidnap Bakugou to make him one of theirs. 


This arc was just fantastic. Probably the most immersive experience I’ve had with the series so far. Sense of danger was real and it was interesting to see how the kids came up with clever ways to escape safe from the threat putting into practice all they’ve learnt and developing teamwork. And it was interesting to see how the differences in the meaning of being not only a hero -but also a human being- among all the members of the class clashed each other when they were facing a complex situation like the kidnapping of one of them when knowing where they could find him and rescue him, in a world where making use of quirks non being a professional is a considered a crime. Who is the real hero, the one who chooses to follow the rules doing nothing while knowing he could do something?  Or the one that thinks for himself in order to do what he considers the right thing for someone in need?


It also gave Deku an opportunity to wow the audience in an epic and emotionally intense fight against a strong villain. While it’s true that the circumstances surrounding this fight seemed rather forced (the Kouta kid was just a tool-character; it was just put in the narrative to make a one-time impact in the main character and to give him a chance to shine) and you could arguably say that Deku won with a dumb asspull (does anyone know where that additional 999.900% came from?), it was still a good moment to show Deku’s hero virtues and quirk-control progression.  Asspull or not, I didn’t care much. At this point, one asspull more, one asspull less, is not going to make any difference in the shounen realm. And you can still say that he managed this because he was been training a hell lot. This was still an inspirational and exciting moment that meant a lot to the protagonist and that’s all that matters.


It was also the arc where we could finally see some real participation from Class B and to know more about them and how they have taken the critical events regarding UA so far.


The conclusion of the arc; the fight between All Might and AFO, it was both great and underwhelming at the same time. Great because it was a killer moment where All Might makes his last act in society as a hero and says goodbye to his hero career, with the whole citizenship still cheering for him to save them once again even after discovering his true physical aspect, teaching everyone that you don’t need to be super muscled and have an imposing figure to be a hero. Along Bakugou’s rescue by his friends, the absolute highlight of the season. 


But at the same time, it felt underwhelming, because it was just too short and because it quickly killed all the intrigue surrounding the big boss coming from S2. He is defeated in a single episode in the middle of the season and all its big attention is quickly lost when it is followed by an arc that wants us to forget everything about it for a while.  However, it wasn’t really much of a trouble when the great part of it closed the arc in such an emotionally intense way.


The second arc, the provisional licenses exam arc, was more less the same tournament arc in S2 just with more schools now. This was an exam that- if passed – it would give our students permission to work as heroes without the supervision of a professional hero. Of course, everyone was going to pass, even the ones that didn’t! Because in case you failed, you could still assist to an extracurricular course to receive training and get the license anyway, so there was never a true stake here, which kind of ruined the whole purpose of the exam.


This second arc was somewhat boring and felt longer than it needed to be. It threw away all the tension built in the first one. It felt underwhelming to see such a dull arc that we had already seen before right after the most compelling first one. Dragon Ball also had tournament arcs for relief in between tension-packed arcs. It worked well because they were breaks inside a bigger story. This time, this arc is the big story. In a 25 episode show, 12 of them are half. In a 100 episode show, it’s only an eighth. These are other of the downsides of the seasonal approach. Weak arcs feel more dragging than what they actually are when you see the big picture of the show.


I think it would have been much better if the provisional license exam arc would have come first and the forest camp arc (clearly more interesting and relevant) -finishing with Bakugou’s rescue and the confrontation between All Might and AFO- would have come after. Narratively speaking it would have worked much better. Tension would have gone upwards rather than downwards throughout the season.


However, while boring, that didn’t mean it was useless. It still did a good job when it comes to the main thread of the show: heroes in training and their personal growth in their path to become them and understand its meaning. Each arc has served this purpose; there is none that feels useless or disposable.  Each one so far has been useful to make them grow, to overcome their fears, their weaknesses, and to understand and think by themselves what makes someone a true hero regardless of what society tells them to think. I think every single arc so far has done a good job in regard to this, and this one was no exception.


Also, school segments are still enjoyable. They allow showing characters in their daily lives and routines when they are not involved in a dangerous fight, which this gives more life and naturalism to the show. They make them more relatable. It makes things more diverse and fun to watch. I would really get tired fast if everything was confrontations and explosions the whole time. Some have complained that these school moments ruin tension. Well, this is a show about teens attending a school after all, so it’s not like you shouldn’t expect a lot of classes and training, the same way nobody ever complained about classes and Quidditch matches scenes that didn’t have anything to do with Voldemort in Harry Potter. It can’t be battles all the time. You need more realism. You need moments to have lighter fun.


Also, now that All Might is gone as the main hero there’s an opportunity now for more interesting things to happen. All Might was the pillar of society that now has to put their faith in someone they have never liked that much. The League of Villains can also take advantage from this fact. There’s a lot of potential in this situation that I hope can be leveraged somewhere in the coming seasons. 



Characters:



I’d say the biggest issue with characters is that the show is now simply introducing too many given the relative run. The cast was already too large to begin with and now they added even more with the other dudes from the other schools and some other secondary villains. We already had 20 students in Class A, 20 in B, like 5 teachers per class. The main and minor villans. More villains. A set of professional heroes. The families. Now the other schools’ guys. And so on. This means…there won’t be much screen-time for everyone, good guys and bad guys. However, I’m glad it’s at least at the same time caring in not abandoning them. Other shounens just forget them in the middle, or simply choose to reduce many of the side-characters as part of the backgrounds. 


Yes, some of them will get more attention, but it’s nothing that you can’t expect from every traditional non-ensemble piece production. In every story there is a main character, secondary and tertiary ones. Nonetheless, I still feel the show manages to integrate all of them organically in the storyline. You see dialogues from everyone in the classroom or training or examination scenes. Nobody feels that is “just there” meaning nothing to the show, even if they are only there for comic relief and joke moments like the purple balls small perverted dude (I still have to remember the names from everyone!). But at the end of the day, everyone will be contributing their tiny grain of sand to convey and enjoyable ride. 


You can really tell BNHA is taking care of its large cast. The show is doing well in giving every one of its characters their fair time to shine, unlike others where only the main ones get the whole attention, despite knowing that some of them will play a more important role in the story. You can criticize the way BNHA is attempting to do this, that it may look forced within the arcs, but at least is doing so and that is always a welcome, and it isn’t forgetting about 50% of its main cast for 50% of the whole damm show.


This has also helped in the thematic department giving more variety and perspectives in the discussion of the role and meaning of being a hero, the clear DNA of the show. Characters also learn from themselves and from the rest in their journey. Everyone has their own ways and motives, and it’s rich to see how their views clash when faced to complex situations. It’s interesting to see how the discussion around what a hero should do and what he should not in the midst of all these dangerous incidents and examinations makes all the characters have second thoughts on the matter.


I’d also like to point that shows like BNHA benefit from having and integrating a huge likable cast. There’s a character for everyone to feel connected to or identified with. Watching how their relationships grow, how their personalities clash and how they have fun altogether is always a pleasure and delight to see.


While every side-character was given a moment to shine, in varying degrees, this time it was really (and finally) Katsuki “Kacchan” Bakugo’s turn to progress in the story, the same way Todoroki and Tenya got their big moments in the previous season. His character finally stops from being just the hot-headed-but-adorable-dude running joke, is given some real fleshing and we finally get to see what he has to say and how he really feels about Deku’s steady progress which he sees as a threat to his superiority.  He can’t understand how this once quirkless and weak childhood “friend” has been getting stronger and more skilled so fast in such a short time and why it was him the one who gained the admiration from All Might, the hero they both idolized, and not himself. And we finally see some true development of shounen’s new emblematic rivalry where the two parts come to terms in the context of a fight. It’s undoubtedly not only one of the highlight of the season, but the series as a whole, resembling past rivalry-clashes like Naruto-Sasuke in Naruto and Goku-Vegeta during the Buu arc in DBZ, given how long-awaited it was and all the emotion and intensity that it carried through. Bakugo for once reveals himself as an insecure and accepts that he can’t have everything under his control and always win as he had always convinced himself he could do. 


Another character that finally was given a minute to say some things in this season was no other than Deku’s lovely mom. As of now, the show almost had relegated as “just the sweet and protective mommy” stereotypical role, supporting his son in everything he wanted to achieve. Turns out that was not exactly the case. Turns out she was not so pleased with everything his son had to live through since he started attending UA and the way the school had been handling the critical and dangerous situations its students had to confront, from breaking his bones multiple times to facing a life-or-death threat from a villain assaulting the school activities, claiming that it would have been better for his son to have remained quirkless and admiring heroes from the outside, which made her relationship with his son more interesting. It was a nice, touching family moment where we could see how their relationship evolved to a new level and how Deku interiorizes in his quest to become a hero his own mother’s feelings about it. 


Speaking about quirkless, some argue that it would have been more interesting for the show that Deku had remained in his original state where he was an extraordinary boy (yes, because in a world where 80% of the population has a quirk, the 20% remaining are the extraordinary ones!), because that would have meant that he would have had to resort to other more interesting ways to prove people that he could also become a hero. UA could admit quirkless people after all, so it was never an impediment.  But as the boy had always firmly believed, being a hero is more than just having a superpower. And even people with superpowers can’t qualify as such. There’s more in a hero than just the special ability one has and how can one master it to put it to society’s benefit. Heroes are defined by their attitudes, values, self-sacrificing spirit and morals, and not so much by the power they were born with. And he could still defend this idea even now that he does have a quirk that will grant him a great responsibility towards society, since society still is relying so much on professional quirksome heroes. He already did it when without a quirk he tried to save Bakugo from the mud villain in S1 even knowing the danger he was facing doing that, and is now doing it too with a quirk when he is willing to go as far as he can -even compromising his own body- to save a boy from being killed by a beastly and merciless human. 


Also, the fact that Deku already is a noble boy who displays these hero virtues since the beginning of his life -which makes All Might see him as his worthy successor- doesn’t imply the character is rendered boring and there is no room for the character to grow on a personal level; now that he’s inherited one-for-all and has accepted the “symbol of peace” torch from All Might, it will be interesting to see how he will deal with this great responsibility towards society , becoming the new number 1 hero everyone will rely on, that already is awaiting for him. Will he be able to bear all that charge in his shoulders? Besides, despite having a clear notion of what being a hero means, this is more about how he overcomes obstacles and learns from real life experiences in his path to be recognized by everyone as the greatest hero. What’s going on for him is to know how he did this. That’s the driver of the show. He already has the values, focus of the show it’s in how he will put them into practice to achieve his goal.



Villains:



I’d say the real main problem of the series so far, which has been hinted since the beginning but now in this season became more evident, is that the villain side of the story is just all over the place and has been totally confusing. In this season you just don’t know who to pay attention to anymore. In S1 you thought it was Shigaraki. In S2, nope, it is Stain… but he was captured within the same season, so it’s not about him anymore, but rather about Shigaraki and this mysterious big boss that gives instructions from the shadows that All Might refers as AFO. Now in S3 is about Shigaraki again and this other villains that were inspired by Stain’s cause to gather, but no, now it’s about AFO which surprised everyone coming into the stage. But this biggest enemy of the show was defeated in an episode. That was all? So I guess he was not that big to begin with. So I guess Shigaraki again, who else? 


However, to an extent, I don’t see this as something completely bad. This is not a world with only one villain; there are many of them. The good news is that this is a series and not a movie where a clear focus in one villain should be put because it’s a single storyline. Spiderman 3 tried to innovate introducing multiple villains in its storyline and miserably failed because of the movie nature. But BNHA, being a series, doesn’t run that risk. In fact, I like how it is trying to escape the “one villain at the time” mold, present in most shounens, this is no show where an enemy defines an arc, this is overarching and we still have a lot to see. All the show needs in regard to its villain side is just more…order. I don’t mind multiple villains at once, but I do mind that their presence should feel better structured and better integrated into the storyline, something in which the show just has to improve upon.


Their motivations have been also weak. When you think of a villain motive, you generally think of something like thirst of power, world domination, world destruction, having revenge for something someone else did them in their past, trying to make his worldview to prevail in a clash of ideologies with the main character, or simply –as a famous superhero movie stated- “to see the world burn”. In sum, to obtain a personal benefit. But it seems like in this world, villains are bad because of the existence of All Might. Without him they have no reason to exist. They don’t really want to see the world burn. They just want them to think and feel that they are not safe, so they need to get rid of All Might, the embodiment of peace and social safety, to get that. That’s what bothers Shigaraki. Shigaraki doesn’t really want to cause destruction or physical pain to people. He just wants to see everyone locked in their homes because of the fear of danger. In what sense does that exactly benefits him? We still don’t know. Maybe we will know somewhere in the future, but I think that after 60 episodes it’s more than enough time to actually do something relevant with your antagonists. 


Stain had the potential to be a more interesting villain because he had more convincing motives, rebelling against professional heroes that act unselfishly expecting big economic compensation and personal glory for their heroic acts rather than truly wanting to help people, but the show opted to put him aside. I don’t know if he’s going to come back further in the show, but being the more interesting villain so far, and one that could truly shake the society paradigms of what it means to be a hero in the hero world, I hope so. Just having inspired (for unknown reasons so far) other villains (that we still don’t know much about) to come together joining the League, is not enough. 


To worsen things, Shigaraki and his squad not only have been a little interesting with little believable motivations gang so far, they have also showed themselves as incredibly dumb.  Did they really think a student that enrolled in a hero school was going to happily be willing to join them, just because his rude and aggressive behavior is more expected from a villain rather than a hero? Or because he does everything for personal glory and not so much for the rest? They dumbly try to drag him to the dark side when they got nothing to offer him and resorted to nothing to emotionally manipulate him. At least they should have better informed themselves about him and his weaknesses to take advantage from those and convince him, the same way Dark Lord Sidious did with Anakin Skywalker in Star Wars. Villains here had no reasons to believe nor any real means to convince Bakugo to become part of their team.



Art, animation and sound:



What feels lacking in an action-packed show like BNHA is a more remarkable OST. In all honesty, the tracks have been so far forgettable. Aside from the powerful “You Say Run”, there’s no single track that had stuck in my mind that I can remember and play there. They’ve failed to match the intensity of the action scenes. But I don’t care that much really. In fact, if something is capable to convey emotions without the help of memorable music then I’d say it’s nothing short of outstanding, and BNHA has proven to do it. Great music is always just a plus, not a must. The presence adds, but the absence doesn’t subtract. Finally, both opening of this season, “Odd Future” and “Make my Story” are amazing catchy tunes, especially the latter for which I have become totally obsessed with this last week.


Voice acting is good also, nothing to complain. They suit the characters and they even do in the dubbed version. 


Art and animation are inconsistent throughout the episodes. You could clearly tell there was an uneven distribution of budget among them. More action-packed episodes were obviously going to be a priority over the more calmed classroom or indoors ones, but that is no excuse for somewhat poorly drawn faces, body-shapes and bad contrasts among characters and backgrounds. I wouldn’t mind this if BNHA was a straight long-runner. But it is not. Moreover, this is Bones we are talking about. They should be more careful like they have proven in the past. 


However, when it comes to action they never fail to deliver, you can really tell these guys know what they do. Nothing to complain here and everything to praise. The vibrant, flashy and stimulating colors perfectly suit the highly energetic vibe of the show, paying homage to western superhero comics. 


Character designs are cool. They all feel unique unlike most of the generic seasonals where everyone has the same face except by hair and eye colors. There’s a distinctive feel on everyone. I know you can say the same for many other shows but this doesn’t mean this isn’t something to be recognized here.



Conclusion:



This was just a mild step back from S2, mainly due to the poor villain buildup, the sharp contrast among the two main arcs of the season where the second felt like an involution and longer than needed, and the excess of introduced characters that are accumulating in a room where there won’t be much space for everyone, but that was all. It doesn’t mean the show is doomed. It doesn’t mean there is no room for improvement. If you didn’t for example have major problems with the weak Greed Island arc coming right in between two heavyweight arcs in Hunter x Hunter then I don’t know why you should have them now here. It was just a weak arc among many and that was it. It is not going to lower down the show the same way any other boring arc in other shounen anime didn’t.


Things are still in a building phase, the stage is still being mounted. People want a climax when this is still development. The problem is that this development has been rather bumpy. It’s like it knows where it wants to get but doesn’t really know the way to get there, like a lost driver in a city he’s never been before. It knows its destination, but just needs some orientation. 


The good news is that the show isn’t over yet, so there’s opportunity for recovery and for it to pull its socks up again. Like that school student that becomes overconfident after nailing the first test, stops studying hard for the next one, performs weak in it, learns from his mistakes and studies hard again for the following ones. It is still on a right path. It’s still entertaining, engaging; personally it's been a long time since I've watched something where I was truly and genuinely interested in watching how the whole story keeps developing and unfolding. 


And it’s also good that it is never trying to be something that it’s not; it doesn’t fall to pretentiousness’s temptation to be something else, different, just to look cooler than the rest, staying true to itself.


It just needs to be better polished and…disciplined. And there’s no reason to think it can’t.

Ya know. I don't think words do this show justice. There's something so special about My Hero Academia for me that it's almost intangible. This season has been incredible. So many amazing moments. Being a manga reader gives you a sort of special insight into how things will go sure, but seeing it animated and acted and with all the music and everything is a whole different experience in my eyes. Going into this season, knowing what would happen, I knew it was going to be great given the material, but I think I might have dominated Bones a bit on just how good it'dbe. Cause this season raised the bar and then some. Really elevated the whole thing. The manga was already a high bar but they some how went beyond that, I think Studio Bones is the real embodiment of Plus Ultra!! They deserve a lot of worthwhile praise and then some.


Now getting into the nitty gritty, this season had it all for me. The Training Camp Arc was such a gut punch, the villains attacking head on like that was crazy to see again. The League is such a cool threat, not an all powerful menace from the jump like we see tons of other shonen villains whom pop up in other series. That whole arc was awesome, it had so much craziness. Deku vs Muscular is one of the top fights of the year no doubt. That moment had me choking up ngl. Deku is such a good boy. Then even after that when Bakugo gets taken away it's such a powerful moment because it hits so close for all our heroes. It was such a gut punch as I said. Them all trying to save him but coming up short was so sad and you could feel their anguish in it.


Next arc being the Hideout Raid Arc was even crazier somehow. Like nuts. Getting the obvious out of the way, All For One. The man. The big dog himself. Master as Shigaraki has called him for so long now. Finally stepping into the light once again. And boy what a showcase it was. That fight with All Might, fantastic all around I bawled like a child throughout most of it tbh. It was everything. Such a high point for the series. It was everything. Talk of the town and then some everywhere you looked I think. One of the best anime moments this year no doubt.  Rest of the arc was crazy good too. All the lead up to the fight was great. The Bakugo Rescue Squad was a sight and funny as hell in their get ups too. It was such a great arc. 


Now the Hero License Exam Arc might not be as crazy as either of those last two. But it was a chance to let the audience catch their breath some after all that madness and all the big shifts the story has just taken. So I respect it for that. The arc itself might not be anything too special, but it had a good share of awesome moments. The introduction of other schools and their students was great. Shiketsu with Inasa, Shishikura, and "Camie" we're all awesome and had great moments. The big showdown so to speak between Todoroki and Inasa was cool as hell. The whole test set up was meh but the actual arc was Damn fun and a needed lighter touch considering all we'd been through in the season thus far. 


I honestly think everything about this season worked so well and especially worked so well together. Seeing the Big 3 at the end made my heart flutter. The finale was so cool seeing Mirio go full power on them just to show how much they still have to learn to become pros. Mirio is an absolute beast. The dude is a prodigy. Love how they show they his quirk is nothing special but it's how he uses it that elevates him. Awesome stuff. This season has been such a blast to see. Some of my favorite material finally being adapted to perfection and then some. Just a damn good time. Love, love, love this show! Another each score and another AOTY contender.


10/10. Go Beyond!!! Plus Ultra!!!!

Boku no Hero Academia is back with another season and this season probably has some of the biggest shifts in it's plot and characters yet!
Spoilers ahead!
Boku no Hero Academia 3 leaves us right after the second season with.....MOAR TRAINING AND EXAMS...yaaaaaaaa
No but seriously Deku and the gang goes through the typical superhero training and exams but within all this comes one of the most pinnacle major shifts into the plot and this review will go into spoiler territory with...All for One vs. All Might and what it means by the end for Deku.
The All for One vs. All Might fight finally shows us the BiggerBad of the entire series, All for One and what he is capable of as well as being the diametric opposite of One for All as well as knowing more about Tomura Shigaraki in the process as well. By all means this fight is the pinnacle for this season in LA's view, as it's the major changing point of Boku no Hero Academia in general, as the resulting situation and what it leads to is both the hero side needing to quickly learn their junior heroes as fast as possible in keeping with All Might's legacy *cough* Deku while the villains are spreading more and more because LA will be spoiling, All Might retires which is why this changes everything, from Boku no Hero Academia's setting and it's beliefs on it's heroes and villains taken to even more extremes and spreading like wildfire as a result of the shake up of the hero system by toppling over with their Number 1# Hero being taken down but not out from the literal stains that Stain smeared over All Might's reputation to the fight against All for One awakening new villains while growing the ones already lurking out of the darkness.


With the entire major scope of Boku no Hero Academia 3 of All for One vs. All Might, well what does this mean for Deku?, well Deku grows as a character both in his determination and beliefs of being a better hero whilst trying to stay in the law this time AND evolving his fighting style to better suit him, honing all his skills and better becoming a hero AND keeping All Might's reputation on the line as a result. Deku grows immensely in this season and that is a no brainer due to the major events that occurs in this season, not just All for One vs. All Might, from solidifying his beliefs as a hero and to be the best to changing his fighting style are great examples, but he also grows through his turbulent rivalry with Bakugo reaching it's apex with this season as well. So in speaking of Bakugo, Bakugo has some personal problems going on with him mainly involving Deku for obvious reasons, which comes into the prospects of him having something of a superiority inferiority complex towards Deku and HIS beliefs of justice grown from All Might as a result thus clashing of Deku and Bakugo being inevitable.  


So with this season being more or less the same in terms of plot mainly of the hero exams and training arcs and this isn't for the norm for Boku no Hero Academia and this is one nitpick many people would say about this season but again LA will say that at least it's what happens in between or around these exams and training arcs that grows it's huge cast as result. Now Boku no Hero Academia's 3rd Season does do well in it's approach of developing it's ensemble cast VERY well once again, due to it's plot structure on a wider scale and looking into many of it's characters simultaneously while working on Deku as the narrative focus. Some major focuses besides Deku within both the hero exam and training camp arcs, Todoroki once again more development this season like he does but this time instead of him opening up his powers through his parental issues as a result this season however looks more in his introspective look at Todoroki almost having the same personality as his father Endevour which manifests itself with one of the newer heroes in the cast, Inasa Yoarashi bringing this out of Todoroki, it's definitely not the same as Todoroki's development from his 2nd Season but this outlook was interesting to say the least and brought on another great battle in the process. Other characters who gets some form of screentime were the League of Evil most notably Himiko Toga voiced by Misato Fukuen and she is something of a wild card for LA for Boku no Hero Academia in LA's faovuirtes as well. Once again LA's favorite character in the ensemble cast are Uraraka and Momo Yaoyorozu but Himiko is definitely interesting to be probably in LA's top 3 for her involvement this season...as much of a playful psycho she is.


In terms of animation done once again by Bones, well they have the consistency down even in it's more bombastically insane fights ESPECIALLY with the All for One vs. All Might fight but in general this has Bones' animation all over it, from it's distinct and eyecatchy character designs, amazingly detailed and outright crazily fluid and impactful battles whilst still being comedic and serious when it calls for it. Bones has the consistency down and under the banner of stunningly great animation to boot...


Voice work, well LA will be here all day if LA talks about the huge cast of characters so LA will keep this short, Kenta Miyake was great as All Might, Nobuhiko Okamoto as Bakugo gets some leverage with amount of adrenaline and somewhat drama Bakugo goes through and Daiki Yamashita as Deku was typical as he's been voicing the character for so long, but like Nobuhikio Okamoto got some leverage with the drama and craziness that ensues this season. To say the least, we have a HUGE cast of character so with that LA will at least bring up Ayane Sakura as Uraraka who gets less screentime than usual as she really doesn't get much screentime or little developments here and there but Ayane Sakura was fine nonetheless even with Uraraka's crush on Deku growing even more which means...Ayane's lovestruck and deredere opening up and on the other side, Misato Fukuen as Himiko was like the controlled pyscho yandere which Misato has something of a niche in and she once again nailed it as Himiko...yeah if this season did something with the long list it already achieved then LA has some obvious liking to Himiko because of this season to say the least what with her itching LA's psychotically playful villains archetype and Himiko with Misato Fukuen voicing her works it quite well *ahem* All for One voiced by Akio Ootsuka had the right cadence to be that smotherly smarmy evil business type and he does GREAT as All for One as a result like damn both he was at times frightening for a character who had no face (no seriously). Overall, the voice cast was widely diverse in personality and many of the characters new and old were great in their role like they should be.


Boku no Hero Academia's 3rd Season vastly improved from it's 2nd Season both improving of it's ideals of being a hero AND a villain and what this means to society as a whole, while massively working on Deku, All Might and Bakugo which had been hinted at multiple times in previous seasons finally coming to something of a resolution in this season, getting to know the League of Villains and their beliefs that clash with Deku, All Might's and the like and let's not to mention the All for One vs. All Might fight being a major turning point for the series and only riles the franchise into new peaks to say the least, from the beliefs of a hero, to the rise of villains and what all this means to society and how they deal with it. Boku no Hero Academia 3 was great to say the least, LA was entrenched in it's lore, it's world and LA didn't see many of it's huge plot twists coming, it's fights were generally amazing and hugely impactful to the plot, interesting and unique characters (both heroes and villains) that don't get left behind and instead evolve with Deku and it's main core cast *cough* well cept Mineta for obvious reasons -sigh- *cough*. Boku no Hero Academia 3 was just crazy bouts of fun and interesting turn of events that it's to be expected that with how LA feels about this season, this season like Boku no Hero Academia in general, LA is favourable to it with how it improves on many of it's fronts that it already improved as well in it's second season and with that yes, Boku no Hero Academia's 3rd Season might be one of LA's favourite animes of the year by the time LA writes this review at the time...and with a 4th season announced, LA will be happy enough to plunge back in and LA will honestly would want to watch more because it's 3rd Season gave us the major turning point of the series, LA would like to see it's repercussions and how it's character deal with it and much more of it's secrets that it hasn't revealed yet...


Boku no Hero Academia 3 is was it's peak but can it go even further beyond....plus ultra?...LA hopes soo...

STORY - 8
ART - 9
SOUND - 9
CHARACTER - 9
ENJOYMENT - 9
Plus Ultra, the Latin phrase we've come to love ever since the epic final showdown on the first season of Boku no Hero Academia. Meaning to go further beyond, it encapsulates the very definition of what Season 3 is all about.
How far can the society of Heroes vs Villains run for without causing major destruction? What does it take to ensure protection, stability, and peace among a changing world full of Quirks? The story wrestles these questions solidly and seeks just how much can heroism triumph against those who wants to crumble society. Upon thevillains' ambush, justice treads over a dangerous tightrope. When more menacing personalities and powers arrive on the doorstep, the suspenseful atmosphere becomes a trigger that sends out a wave of harsh realities towards both students and pro heroes alike. This has now turned into a stage to protect. As new insights are revealed within the evolving villainy allegiances, characters step outside of their comfort zone to battle against destruction. Emotions whirl around, strategies and moves are formed to ensure the best way out, and heroic resolutions truly shine to guard society from the flames. All these mayhems not only add to just be bursting with tense goosebumps or powerful excitements, there's also the influential message of the symbolical justice passing down onto the next generation. Ultimately, they're the next ones who have to fight. And to transition with this succeeding group of heroes, additional focus is given to more hero schools out there. A showcase of developmental progresses and relationships are shown within the students of Class 1A as they face against other students. Their growth ever since the beginning feels very tangible now and it's this aspect that answers why they are deserving to become society's future heroes. They will continue to go further beyond.\n\n
Following up after a great production during the second season, this season carries on with nuclear excitement. Shockwaves after shockwaves of intensity are sent through the audiovisual works produced by Bones. With their maintained consistency, the enjoyment hardly ever stagnated, leaving a solid set of episodes behind. And the proofs are found right on the battlefield. Among the powers of Quirks lie a combat zone full of the smokes and ashes caused by destruction. The animation takes precedent when it comes to focus over a wide array of moves. Not only does this help to give all sorts of lively forms, it also gives them motion on a heightened level. Seeing the characters move about a dynamic battlefield with energies and dangers everywhere enliven the action. This is further reinforced by other visual techniques such as camera shakes and character expressions, particularly the ones evoked by the villains. Their expressions are the embodiment of society's crumblers, the ones who threaten the heroes with heavy influence. In a way, it does give this season more of an emotional weight compared to previous seasons. Facing off against their foes, those they have to beat, will definitely raise the stakes. It's during these times where the voice actors express their skillful talents. They've accomplished a way to tell a powerful story, eliciting a sense of raging strength to never give up. And it doesn't just stop there. All the potent feelings didn't just come from the character's voice. Because in the background, bolstering soundtracks boost this season off with a hype that goes further beyond the horizon.\n\n
Season 3 of Boku no Hero Academia is a strength that maximizes what it's like to have a heroic identity. To watch them pit against many tough threats and situations, there's really no other reason than a straightforward one as to why I kept on watching them. It's simple. They are also my heroes.

So basically this is a show where kids with superpowers fight other kids with superpowers, it's kind of like X-men if X-men were like 15 and had tournaments where they fight each other with some "beat the bad guy" arcs thrown in between. 
Most of these kids doesn't really have any kind of original or interesting superpowers and that would be okay... if it weren't for the main character. 
The main character has the most boring power of all, it's literally just super strength. They tried to offset that by making it so he has trouble using it at first but of course he overcomeshis own limitations so each time I just rolled my eyes because just like with any other shounen anime the limitations are only temporary. \n
I do not recommend this anime but at the same time it's not bad and I like it, it's just nothing special really.

When I watch the previous seasons of Boku No Hero Academia I always ask myself "How on earth are they going to top this season?" anxiously awaiting the next season that they release and I'm never dissapointed & that's only a rare gem you can find with a few select series. A series that manages to do what the previous season did, but better. This season already has my favourite episode of any BNHA episode to date and i'm sure a few reading this can already guess what episode that may be.
Story (10/10): The story is pretty straight forward and easy to follow. Students jointhe U.A to become heroes and they go through multiple different training courses to achieve that dream. The thing that captivates me the most about the story is that they never fall off pace. The pacing is adapted perfectly and you can see the studio hasnt lost track on where they're trying to take the story in retrospect of what they're trying to adapt from the manga in each episode and always manage to include even the smallest details from the manga. The story is easily a perfect 10/10 for me. The story doesn't lose focus of where it's trying to go and that's honestly one of the most important aspects of any anime. 


Art (10/10): Well this is pretty self-explanatory.. Studio Bones is animating it. The art in this show is phenomenal and has an incredible amount of detail scattered through the entire anime. I think this anime was made for Bones to adapt, because honestly the studio is well known for always putting so much art detail into the animes they create and it's noted here exteremely well. It's honestly sometimes hard to go back to other animes and watch the animation after coming out of a BNHA episode because its THAT well-animated and detailed you find it hard to adjust to sub-par animation from other adaptions. 10 out of 10.


Sound (10/10): When you have soundtracks implemented into the anime, you want it to capture the moment. You want the OST to be able to make you feel what exactly is happening in those important scenes & make you feel what the characters are feeling, right? Well this season does one of the best jobs out of any anime I've watched in doing exactly that. I'm always in a rollercoaster of emotions when OST's from this anime play, becaase they do such a perfect job of capturing the moment and mood setting it's hard not to feel for the scenes that take place. Any soundtrack that manages to capture their audience and pull them in with emotions nails it. 10 out of 10.


Character (10/10) - I think this is one of the best aspects about BNHA even though I love practically everything about this anime and this particular season so far. Character development is such a cruical key part of any anime in order to move the story forward. You'd think with that amount of characters BNHA normally has including Class A it would be hard to devlop all the character traits in a little amount of time, but they put so much consideration even into the supporting characters and that gains my respect. Animes these days just focus on the MC's development and they've done an outstanding job with Deku's character and they've made his development more realistic than any other shounen anime's MC development, but they've really focused on not just the MC's development and focused on everyone as a whole and that's something i commend this season for doing also. We're only 8 epiosdes in as i write this review, but can already tell you that theres much more character development ready to come. 10 out of 10.


Enjoyment/Overall (10/10) - I'll put these two sections into two as it'll make it much easier for me. What I love about this season is that they take what Season 1 & 2 did and make it better. Season 1 & 2 are by no means bad at all and they're great in their own rights, but so far I've had the most fun with this season and I think this season is greatly worth a shot. It has if not some of the most important arc's in the entire show so far and to me it's definatly worth the watch if you've watched the first two seasons or only watched some of BNHA and want to reconsider getting into it. YES 100%!


I hope you enjoyed reading my review as much as I enjoyed creating it! i'm a little new to reviewing yeah! Have a lovely day and again, thank you for reading!

WOW! Time to write my first actual review.
Currently, Boku no Hero Academia has the potential to be one of the greatest Shounen series of all time, along with my all-time-great: Hunter x Hunter.
However I know for a FACT that it is too early to put this title along with the likes of HXH or FMA:B, but it still holds up as one the best currently airing anime.
Story: 8/10
While not so much actual *plot* has been happening throughout this season (and the series in general), the story is still compelling and filled with emotion. Though the overarching plot has been sort of... dull.
Hold up! Before youwrite off this review, what I mean by that is the story only is just beginning. Let's rehash on what's ACTUALLY happened so far. 1. Deku meets All Might and starts training. 2. Villains invade UA. 3. Students Fight in a TOURNAMENT ARC (WOOHOO), also as a method of development. 4. Villains invade Hosu City, and fail. 5. More training at camp. 6. Villains invade camp and fail, but this time they're a tiny bit more successful. Notice a pattern? Yeah me too. Basically, its A: Students train, then B: Villains invade. Rinse and repeat 3 times. And the villains fail all 3 attempts. 

Then FINALLY, the story decides to take a turn when All For One shows up and decides to spice it up. And without spoiling anything, this is the reason why I decided to give the story a 8/10 instead of 7/10. 

MHA has always been about the clash of ideals. In every conflict, every character is fighting for the sake of their own beliefs. Bakugo vs Midoriya, All Might vs Nomu (Ok, that one's an exception), Midoriya vs Todoroki, Stain vs Students. Every fight tells a unique story and I firmly believe that is what drives the plot. The overarching story doesn't matter (for now at least) because of the strong connection that we have built with the characters in this series. And all credit is due to the masterful storytelling of each character, done by the main man Horikoshi and Studio Bones. Because of the emotional connection I have with each and every one of my favorite characters on this show, I give the story a strong 8/10. Mostly because of the lack of *actual content* but is strongly redeemed by it's character focused narratives.



Art/Animation: 10/10

I'm not usually one to complain about animation and art. I mean, I've sat through 800 episodes of One Piece, which is not particularly known because of it's animation (quite the opposite really). However trust me when I say this: Studio Bones have stepped it up this season with episode 11 being THE MOST memorable episode in the series (so far), largely due to the quality of animation. The fights, as you'd expect, feel fluid and dynamic, with every punch or injury feeling gritty and real. 

Besides some awkward expressions of characters on some frames, the episodes are all well animated and drawn. But then again, I'm not really one to care that much for such things, so this might not be an accurate review of this section.

Props to Bones anyways.



Sound:I KEEP MY IDEALS/10

Music (OST and OP/ED)-

This is an absolute 10/10 for me. I have blasted the opening to this season at least 3 times a day since it started growing on me.  I listen to it while driving, while doing homework, and just when I'm chilling in my room. I ABSOLUTELY LOVE IT. I haven't paid much attention to the ending though. One of these days I might give it a try. 

Anyways, THE OSTs this season ARE AMAZING AF. It's a wonder how they've been pulling off hype scene after hype scene without using the legendary track of "You Say Run". Every OST they've produced so far gets the blood pumping and makes you emotional to the core. I've cried at least 3 times this season, largely due to the music.

Voice Acting- Japan have the finest voice actors in za whole warudo. Of course there aren't any complaints here.



Character:10/10

I truly believe this is the whole selling point of MHA, since every story and conflict involves solely around this series' characters and their development. While not a lot of characters have been shed the spotlight this season, other than the ones that we ACTUALLY care about (let's be honest, does anyone care about sugar rush dude, Aoyama, Cero, or Ojiro?). The interactions between the classmates of class 1-A is what truly makes this series great. And overall, the cast it VERY strong. Most of what I want to say has already been said in the story section, since I REALLY do believe that the core of MHA's story IS in its characters (so far).



Enjoyment: 12/10

I've laughed, cried, and jumped out of my seat while knocking over my bowl of cereal. ALL IN THE SAME EPISODE. It's needless to say that this is just a pure and fun show. Even if you're not particularly into Shounen or fighting anime, it's still very entertaining to watch. Every Saturday I look forward to watching it either with a friend, or huddled up in my room with a bowl of chips. 



Overall: 9/10

This anime might just be the one to break the barrier between the mainstream audience and the traditional anime audience. More than ever, I've witnessed countless people get into anime because of this particular series. Some of my friends who have had the firm belief that anime is for weebs and nerds, have begun watching this show THEMSELVES. And that really makes me happy since anime is finally getting the appreciation it deserves, through this AMAZING series. 

I gave this a 9/10, not because of any problems I see with it, but rather the potential that I believe it can achieve. Three years ago, when I first saw this series airing, I did not see it would grow to be the Shounen super power it is today. The story still has a ways to go before it reaches the climax, but so far, it is still an astounding series. There is a high probability that I might return to this review and give it a 10/10, after this season ends. But we'll see.

Boku no Hero (almost) single-handedly redeems shonen today. The few things that that I dislike about BnH are more things that I dislike about shonen anime in general. 
It runs a dynamic storyline. Each arc is sized perfectly (not overdrawn). Each episode parallels smoking a cigar over a cigarette: In other words, individual episodes of marathon anime (~CIGARETTES~) don't have the same velocity and enjoyment as the powerful, individual episodes of BnH (~CIGARS~). Halfway through the third season and I'm more addicted now than I was in the beginning. 
Also, this show really nails the openings (title sequences). I mean it really fucking nails them.They're not just some collage scenes from upcoming episodes. They're a packed one minute thirty second appetizers that somehow manage to serve up the spice of the show without spoiling - they build appetite. When I think of some of the most enjoyable openings I have watched, this places amongst them. In comparison, OPs from Naruto or Cowboy Bebop are more iconic. 


One mistake many shonen make is that they are overly apparent about the persona of characters. Just for a quick example, Bleach: it's obvious who that Aizen is a cunt and Ichigo is this high school hero. Obviously they're geared towards kids, but nowadays many older teens are still hooked onto shonen, so they (we) need a bit more psychological stimulation. However, too much psychological questioning would definitely make an anime lose its shonen status, like Fate/Stay Night. This is where BnH fosters balance: it delve just deep enough into the psychological aspect without losing its extremely-fun-to-watch episodes. 


Hero-Killer Stain, who [spoiler] died in the previous season, perfectly sets up the psychological element for the entire show - the viewers wonder whether or not the heros are all that great or not. "To truly accomplish anything... one needs will and conviction. Those without it... the weak ones.. They'll be weeded out. It's only natural. That's why you're about to die."


Boku no Hero is definitely worth the watch. Eat up your shonen pride and just enjoy it. No one's judging.
