I mean if you've watched the first 2 season you're guaranteed watching this and it's got the best moments of the show so far somehow surpassing the Deku/ Todoroki fight. My bias won't let me drop this season from a 10/10. A more critical overview of it the show probably lands at an 8/10 due to the fact that after the training camp and rescue arc the provisional license arc is arguably the weakest in the show thus far as well as the manga. That's not a knock against the arc I really enjoy what this arc does and if in my opinion the weakestarc lands brings the show down to an 9/10 (averaged cause the training camp/rescue arc is easily 10/10) then the show is still damn good.

I feel this was a solid season. It introduced us to a lot of aspects about the world that were fun. A lot of quirks that were interesting to see in action, and characters that I hope are expanded upon later. It does get sloppy in the overall planning and character motivations departments that completely take you out of what is happening. 
The first half of the season is very strong. It answers some great questions about the world and introduces some great character arcs for the main character to have achieved. Him actually saving someone and being fulfilled by it is a cozy littlearc that also bled into the character he was saving in very uplifting ways. The expansion on the MC's mother was very welcome. She acts very much like a mother and the iteration between All Might and her was very emotionally satisfying. Every character that is expanded upon acts in very real and emotionally relateable ways. This leads into one of the most detours of the series where it greatly explains a lot about All Might and the arch nemesis that the previous seasons where debating. The climax is very emotional. You will most likely know how it ends, but it is one of the best shonen moments because of how the character of All Might was built up for so long.


The problems start to arise in the second half. Not entirely because of how it is built, but the major character motivations and results. A lot of it stems from not following the very first line it lays down in the series about no one being equal. For example, it feels it has to always get every single character from the class to the same point. It undermines what it wants to do about showing some of these characters fail. A lot of deus ex machina or saved by the bell types of scenarios that save characters who failed from their failures or character flaws. So when you know every single character is going to get to a certain point then there is no tension, especially after the first arc in this season. Because of the first arc and then leading into the second half everything feels so flat. The second season for instance had a competition, and the stakes there did not feel flat compared to the second half of that season. No one is in any real danger and it is very clear that this is not the only chance they will be able to complete this task. The MC, though continues to be a very great voice in the competition though. He shows leadership skills and learns more about independence versus cooperation in relation to becoming a hero. 


The most underwhelming character arcs in the second part of the season are with another very powerful user who has a vendetta against a student from the main class. The teenager from another school hates him and his family for very petty reasons. Like his father not giving an autograph. Basically a few of these petty actions. This hatred is so pathetic and it is not humored in that way so it comes off very self important. They do this when one of the people he hates could easily be hated because the father is literally explained to be a wife beating, eugenics supporter, who buys his wife to impregnate her for his own selfish purposes. He is already pretty evil and it still focuses on such a petty thing he has done. In addition, the relationship between this father and son is so fleshed out from what was introduced before. The son is basically a eugenics project and it never really expands upon what that means. His actual feelings are not really touched on at all through the season. Also, the father is never really touched on about his eugenics or actions and it still accepted as a hero and not in a way where it takes a look at the hierarchy in place from a cynical point of view. They are basically saying that yeah what he did was bad and hoping you forget about it for now until they come up with something. Its very sloppy. 


The main Comic relief character, Minoru, is still very annoying and creepy. He is a creep and his fixation of women is not funny as much as it is dangerous. It plays it like a joke, but he is just accepted anyway which does not make much sense. He is such a boring character too. He does not do much and does not add to anything besides just being an excuse to focus on underage girls which makes his appearance even more creepy from the point of a viewer. 


I love romance, but the main romance in this series, that was introduced is so lazy. Obviously we know who will eventually end up with some romance, but it does not escalate their relationship in any way. It does not show them hanging out alone together or expanding up their relationship. This is kind of minor though because the girl has a crush and those tend to be pretty surface based. But it introduces that the MC is interested in her too in the first season so for him to basically forget about it, unless necessary, makes it seem like it is very one sided. What is annoying is it takes so long for this girl to even realize her infatuation with the MC that it just becomes an annoyance rather than an escalation. What it does right is it shows that she is attracted to the MC's qualities and appearance in addition to his actions promoting his growth. I get what it wants to go for, but it stumbles on how they grow to like each other. 


The last thing is the focus on the two rivals towards the end. Their fights make the focus something completely adjacent to what it actually is and makes it seem resolved. The MC loves his rival so much and the rival hates him because he is insecure about someone who was once quirkless looking at him as though he was better. The problem arises when the rival is treated as though he was simply born a better person. His anger stems from his own pride being undermined, but then it throws in how he was kidnapped from earlier in the season. It is a mess of a final confrontation because it has no clear point that it gets confusing. The MC finally stands up for himself, but it is to help his rival rather than stand up for him, but he is also standing up for him, and the rival feels like he isnt good enough, but he knows he is good enough. It gets really confusing when all this is compounded and contradictory. It should focus on why the rivals views are wrong and their mutual respect at the end or something akin to that. 


this may seem negative, but I still did have fun. I hope they explore some of the themes that they introduced in the beginning like hierarchical structures, eugenics, and other fascist themes, but it seems to be going down a more generic route. It is still fresh, and an enjoyable watch.

Sometimes I like starting out by going through the weaknesses of a show which I why I actually want to mention, Boku no Hero Academia is truly one of my favorite tv-shows. It's got everything a superhero anime needs - cool designs, over the top action beautifully animated by Studio Bones and a protagonist slowly learning how to become the strongest hero. A shounen show with some of the tropes and definitely all of the strengths. 
It does unfortunately have some of the anime worlds', or should I say manga worlds' weaknesses - such as a pervy character being played off for fun and sometimespretty still frames during dialogue. A character will seem very simple, then infodumps will be made during a battle which works in a manga but feels a bit stilted when you constantly go from adrenaline pumping power fests to down-to-earth chilling scenes of horror-imagery. There's also a questionable choice of sakuga-moment (seemingly perfect flow in animation, which is rare as it will drain the budget) which I felt could have been used in THE big showdown of the season.

Season 3 is also the weakest one so far in terms of story, as it becomes a bit unfocused.


By the miracle of great voice acting, music and last but NOT least, beautiful animation I forgive each and every one of those faults. I enjoyed the frikkin helooza out of this show. It is a mix of the Japanese medium and the American-style superhero stories. Whilst season 2 had the strongest episodes so far, this one has truly developed into an ensemble show where you wanted to see all the characters grow beyond their limits and seeing that new episode available was enough to get my blood pumping.

The third season of Boku No Hero Academia was kind of a bummer. 
I don't remember if I felt this way about previous seasons, but this time around the pacing was awful. I think the show is too ambitious and not enough happens per season. 
During the training camp arc, their focus was just all over the place. Like that arc had some amazing fights in it... but there are too many characters. Taking the time to zero in on each of their quirks and to show their growth/fighting just really bogged down the series for me. Like the chaos that broke out with thevillains descending on the camp? In real time that fight was probably less than an hour long but it was SO MANY EPISODES and not enough actually happened per episode!!! The highlight of that arc was Midoriya's fight with Muscular because it definitely still had his emotions during the fight, but there were less cut scenes with him being deep in thought and more action instead. 


Although this won't happen, I think the series would benefit from axing 3/4 of the characters. Focus on the main students (Midoriya, Todoroki, Bakugo, Uraraka, & Iida) ...I'd even settle for just the first three to be honest)), a few of the pro heroes/villains and the story would be infinitely better. 


All Might's fight against All For One was great and definitely a really good arc within the season. I didn't even mind the exposition of his students as they watched in horror. The repercussions and fall out of All Might exhausting his power and stepping down as the Symbol of Peace was really great too. I was interested in seeing what would happen with Midoriya because of it this season... but literally nothing happened. BUZZKILL. This is where the season stopped being good. Everything after that went downhill SIGNIFICANTLY. 


I was really disappointed and at most times bored. Like yes, of course as a lover of slice of life, shoujo and characters being happy, I loved the idea of the students living in dorms and seeing what their life is like there! Really, I enjoyed that... but it just felt like a distraction from the story. Like more mud to trudge through to get to the meat of the season. I felt it a bit anxiety inducing that the story wasn't moving fast enough, like the episodes were just ticking by and really nothing was happening. 


Any fighting that took place was too slow and FULL OF EXPOSITION. Midoriya vs Bakugo was such a letdown. It was mostly just cut shots of them being overcome with emotion and flowery words. (I watch a ton of romance anime, I'm not saying emotions/emotional scenes are bad, but I am ONLY watching BNHA for its action and it being a hero series!!!) This could've been the true highlight of the season! I mean, c'mon we've been waiting for this fight for THREE SEASONS. 


I also don't find it believable that despite the way that Bakugo has TRULY tormented Midoriya over the years, treated him like absolute garbage and even inspired his hero name Deku ('Nothing' ) that Midoriya STILL CALLS HIM KA-CHAN? I'M SORRY, THAT IS CRAZY TO ME. I kept seeing reactions to that one scene where Bakugo gives him that backhanded compliment about him making One for All his own power on twitter and everyone's like OH MY GOD, HOW CUTE!!! THAT'S SO GREAT OF BAKUGO!! This kid does the bare minimum. Don't get me wrong, I like Bakugo because he's a ruthless fighter and I think he can be funny... but he's still a jerk. I don't understand how Midoriya has a sense of loyalty to him and considers him a friend. Also, if Midoriya really went all out, he could've won that fight - that bugged me too.


***Also Mineta needs to be removed immediately and the fact that he got his provisional license despite cowering in fear for the majority of the exam INFURIATED ME. Completely unrealistic. Please kill him off - he's not funny at all he's just disgusting.***


I love Shoto Todoroki the most, though. I think his character is truly great and his character design is lovely. His conflicting emotions, personality and overall growth is one of the best parts of the series. I wish they'd do a spinoff of just him, his relationship with his father, Endeavor, and overcoming his own demons. I find him more compelling than Midoriya even though he was mostly in the background of this season. 


I have not yet read the manga, but I wonder if the pacing is faster. I think I'll check it out this fall and if it's less bulky, I might switch to it exclusively. 


I wanted to like this season more, truly I did. But the second half of the season just seemed a bit ridiculous to me. Even in the season finale when it ended, I was like... 'that's it?'. I'm not sure if I'll watch the fourth season. Positives for the third season of Boku No Hero Academia include: the art was fantastic, the voice acting was great, I really liked the characters and also getting a glimpse into their personal lives this season, and the big fights were pretty great (particularly Midoriya vs Muscular). Worth checking out if you're invested in these characters and like how the story has been progressing.
